column2: Blood of the Grass-Devil
Darien de Tyrone became known as the "Devil-in-the-Grass" after destroying an invading Columbian army. His legendary ambush in the bayous is studied to this day.
Burntower Blood
An unpopular and sinful minor earl, Constantine Burntower would likely be forgotten, if not for his notorious debauchery and many bastard offspring.
Tregart Blood
A Hudsonian national hero. Darius Tregart distinguished himself at the Battle of Saratoga, where he slew Zadok Mahonic in a man-to-man duel.
Duque Blood
Renato I finally ended the vicious strife between the scions of el Tizón. His own scions would lose the Empire to the plotters of Ixcateopan. A complex legacy, to say the least.
Bragança Blood
Alexandre Cantarini claimed descent from the legendary pre-event rulers of Brazil. This remains unproven, but his descendants have ruled the restored Empire for centuries.
Dandridge Blood
Marcellus Dandridge was awarded the Medal of Honor for his service to America. He was later elected President on the back of that fame.
Blood of Solomon
Solomon King was a paragon of virtue and bravery, who saved New England from the tyranny of Vincent II. His untimely death would undo his accomplishments.
Fenimore Blood
One of New England's most storied dynasties, House Fenimore ruled Maine even before the rise of the Mahonics. They would eventually become the last kings of New England.
Silvermount Blood
An adventurer and Rough Rider, Granger Silvermount's reputation was fearsome even before his conquests. His descendants have done much to maintain that reputation.
Ponderosa Blood
The Ponderosa family have been Gaia's Western bulwark for centuries, most famously against the Trailwalker Silvermounts of Clearwater.
Bravo Blood
After the Plan of Ixcateopan, the Cajita Gaspar Reyes seized the opportunity and carved out an independent Fidencista kingdom in Rio Bravo.
Cambariday Blood
Kimball Cambariday rose from obscure origins as an adventurer and ruthlessly exploited a power vacuum to seize Iowa for himself.
Blood of Aureliano
After the disaster of Ixcateopan, Aureliano Gabsol was animated by a heroic passion to save México. Despite his bravado, his campaigns brought only mixed results.
